comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Vivid description of this occasion at 11:30 am on 21/08/1908 in the SMH of the following day 22/081908 p.13 onwards - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14987360 . READ ALL ABOUT IT!
" . . . The welcome Itself was short - and may have been sweet for all that one could hear. From the stands It was hard to realize that anything was happening. A cluster of gentlemen on the red carpet between white pillars, the wide green sweep of the park, the dark, silent battalions massed in front; the great dark trees behind; a man in a felt hat, out in the front of everyone, hanging for dear life on to a tripod and grimly working what seemed a maxim gun, and was a cinematograph, A wide platform, with about 20 cameras like long-logged, weak-jointed flamingoes craning their inquisitive necks over the troops; three or four photographers with their tripods under their arms bolting down the sacred lawn; and a grimy fox terrier scratching his ribs under the very rifles of the guard of honour . . . "

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Ha! Very vivid description. The visit caused quite a stir I believe, and a number of US sailors enjoyed themselves so much they stayed behind! See our blog for other collection items from this historic visit: bit.ly/IEoF7B
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
